Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the number of persons who have become unemployed as a result of companies going into receivership in the past six months.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Kavanagh) Liam Kavanagh
Speaker.P: The only relevant information available to my Department regarding unemployment resulting from receiverships is that contained in formal notifications of redundancies furnished under the Redundancy Payments Acts, 1967 to 1979, by the receivers concerned. These Acts, however, relate only to workers who are fully insurable and who have been employed for a minimum of two years.

Of the 53 receivers whose appointments were notified to the Registrar of Companies in 1983 up to 24 June statutory notifications of redundancies have been received in my Department in 26 cases. The total number of proposed redundancies involved is 1,096.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Pay Comparisons.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Public Service the rank, in terms of salary in the Public Service, that compares with that of a Deputy and Senator.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Boland) John Boland
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Boland)
Speaker.P: There is no accepted comparision for pay purposes between TDs and Senators and ranks in the public service.

The annual allowance payable at present to a TD, £13,802, lies within the salary scale for the civil service grade of assistant principal, £12,721 to £15,107. The annual allowance payable at present to a Senator, £7,619, lies within the salary scale for the civil service grade of executive officer, £5,417 to £10,533. It might be added in this regard that the Review Body on Higher Remuneration in the Public Sector, who carried out a survey of the hours of work and other occupations of parliamentarians in connection with their 1972 report, concluded that it was not appropriate for them, in proposing the level of allowance for Senators, to proceed on the basis of unqualified comparisions with full-time occupations.

MainHeading.P: It is relevant, as regards level of remuneration, to add that the phased increases provided for in the Public Service pay agreement of December 1981, 2 per cent (or £4 a week, whichever is the greater) from 1 December 1981, 6 per cent from 1 March 1982 and 5 per cent from 1 January 1983, were applied to the salaries of the civil service grades referred to; they have not been applied to the allowances of TDs and Senators. Had they been, the annual allowance payable to a TD would now be £15,669 which lies between the maximum of the scale for assistant principal and the minimum (£16,370) of the scale for principal. A Senator would now receive £8,713 which lies within the scales for a number of general civil service grades i.e. administrative officers, executive officer and staff officer.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Brady Mr. G. Brady
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for the Public Service if it is his intention to establish the office of Ombudsman; if so, if he will outline the cost.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Boland) John Boland
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Public Service (Mr. Boland)
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is probably aware the previous Government made no provision in the Estimates for 1983 for the establishment of the office; accordingly, resources are not available in the current year to set up the office. However, I wish to assure the Deputy that, within these constraints, it is my intention to have the office of Ombudsman established as soon as possible.
As regards the cost of the office of Ombudsman the Ombudsman Act, 1980 provides that the person appointed as Ombudsman be paid a salary equivalent to that of a High Court Judge.
Additional costs relating to staff salaries, office expenses etc. would also arise and these will be directly related to the volume of work coming before the Ombudsman.

asked the Minister for Fisheries and Forestry if he is satisfied that action taken by the Naval Service vessel off Donegal coast over the past two weeks is justified; if Naval Service patrols are covering all salmon fishing activities around our coast; if so, if they are acting in a similar manner; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole) Paddy O'Toole
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Fisheries and Forestry (Mr. O'Toole)
Speaker.P: I am satisfied that it is necessary to use the Naval Service as an aid to the civil power in the enforcement of statutory salmon conservation measures at sea and that the action taken by the Naval Service to that end is justified. In 1983 Naval patrols are covering all salmon fishing areas on a rota basis in so far as resources permit.
Salmon conservation measures are designed to safeguard the future of our badly depleted salmon stocks in the interests of Irish fishermen.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Purchase of Property Abroad.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the rules and regulations that apply to Irish citizens purchasing holiday homes abroad; and the guidelines, if any, applicable.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: Under Exchange Control regulations all purchases of personal property abroad by Irish residents must have specific approval from the Central Bank.

MainHeading.P: Where the property is located outside the EEC, the Central Bank will consider applications to purchase one property per family unit at a cost not exceeding £20,000. The full amount of the purchase price must be financed by way of foreign currency borrowing. More favourable rules apply for purchases within the EEC but again specific approval by the Central Bank is required in each case. The Exchange Control Acts lay down heavy penalties, which may include a fine or imprisonment or both, for breaches of the regulations. A detailed information notice on purchase of property for personal use abroad is available from the Central Bank. A copy is being sent to the Deputy.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Hospital Service Cards.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Health the reason no allowance is made for the number of children in a family when considering eligibility for hospital service cards; when he will be in a position to do so; if he accepts that a married couple with five children are not in the same position financially as a couple with no family if they both have the same income; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.P: The persons who are entitled to hospital services cards are those whose incomes in the year ended 5 April, 1983 were less than £11,000. These cards refer principally to entitlement to free hospital consultant services.

MainHeading.P: The criterion of eligibility for a hospital services card is income. Acceptable evidence of income can be made available in documentation which is routinely provided for income tax purposes. It was not practicable, when these eligibility arrangements were being introduced, to include other criteria of eligibility, such as the number of dependant children in a family, because of the major administrative burden which would be imposed on the staffs of health boards and hospitals in establishing the accuracy of this information. However, it has been provided that a hospital services card may be issued to a person with income over the limit if it is established that the required services cannot be provided without undue hardship. The number of dependants is taken into account in deciding whether hardship might arise.

I should point out that the hospital services card relates mainly to eligibility for free hospital consultant services. All persons, whether they are eligible for hospital services cards or not, are entitled to hospital services in public wards without charge by the hospital. Persons who may be liable for consultant charges can, and in most cases do, provide for payment of these charges through membership of the Voluntary Health Insurance Board. I accept that a married couple with five children may not be in the same position financially as a couple with no family if they both have the same income. I am having the entire subject of hospital eligibility arrangements reviewed. The matters which are raised in this question will be included in this review.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if he will review the system of dealing with the matter of partial pensions payable to persons in receipt of British retirement pensions in view of the typically long delays in deciding their eligibility.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond) Barry Desmond
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)
Speaker.P: The British insurance record of a retirement pension claimant who has been insurably employed in Ireland and in Britain must be obtained in order to determine his entitlement under EEC regulations on social security, if his Irish record is not sufficient to qualify him for the pension under the Social Welfare Acts. The British record is normally supplied by the Department of Health and Social Security, Newcastle-upon-Tyne, within three weeks if the claimant quotes his British National Health Insurance number. The delays referred to by the Deputy usually occur in cases where the claimants cannot quote their British numbers.

The procedures followed in these cases are necessary in order to comply with the provisions of the EEC regulations on social security, insofar as they affect the pension entitlements of persons who have worked in more than one EEC Member State. The persons concerned are advised to send in their claims well in advance of retirement pension age in order to enable the relevant records to be obtained in good time. Under the regulations a claim may be made up to three months before reaching pension age.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. B. Desmond)

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Noonan, Limerick East) Michael Noonan
Speaker.P: Limerick East): The Garda authorities have informed me that they do not consider that the provision of a Garda station at Orwell Park would be warranted. They report that foot and mobile patrols from Rathfarnham station operate in the Orwell Park area to the maximum extent possible having regard to overall resources and other demands on Garda services.
